  • 欧盟领导人开始讨论2024-27年共同预算修订
  • 德国总理表示欧盟将向乌克兰提供资金
  • 斯洛伐克新总理加入批评欧盟对乌克兰立场的行列
  • 菲科和欧尔班都没有拒绝向乌克兰提供更多援助

大多数欧盟领导人周五支持向乌克兰提供更多财政支持，以对抗俄罗斯的入侵，但匈牙利和斯洛伐克在欧盟需要在12月一致做出决定之前表示保留。

欧盟执行官提议，欧盟27个国家在修改共同预算时投入更多资金，为2027年之前的额外支出提供资金，包括向基辅提供500亿欧元（528亿美元）的新援助。

德国总理奥拉夫·肖尔茨在布鲁塞尔峰会上与欧盟同行会谈后表示：“我的印象是，我们将决定乌克兰金融稳定的必要条件。” “而且我认为部分不同的具体评估不会影响这一点。”

总部位于布鲁塞尔的欧盟执行委员会本周表示，自俄罗斯 2022 年 2 月入侵以来，欧盟对乌克兰的支持总额已接近 830 亿欧元。

除了向乌克兰提供资金和武器外，欧盟还对俄罗斯实施了多轮制裁。这次峰会旨在强调即使中东爆发新的战争，欧盟仍对基辅的坚定支持。

欧盟领导人发表联合声明称：“欧盟将继续向乌克兰及其人民提供强有力的金融、经济、人道主义、军事和外交支持。”

斯洛伐克加入匈牙利

匈牙利一直是欧盟对该政策最直言不讳的批评者。

斯洛伐克的罗伯特·菲科周三参加了他第四次担任总理以来的首次欧盟峰会，他也采取了类似的立场。

欧尔班周五刚与俄罗斯总统普京会面后表示，欧盟向乌克兰提供资金和军事援助的战略已经失败。

“乌克兰人不会在战场上获胜，”他说道。峰会开始时的镜头显示，他独自一人站着，而其他欧盟领导人在抵达讨论室时互相打招呼。

欧尔班还表示，他不会支持目前形式的欧盟预算修订提案，其中包括向基辅提供 500 亿美元的新援助。

但他也没有完全拒绝该提议，暗示存在讨价还价的空间。

与此同时，布达佩斯正试图释放欧盟预算中专门用于匈牙利的数十亿美元援助，但由于欧尔班破坏民主的指控而被欧盟委员会冻结。

根据菲科办公室的一份声明，菲科表示乌克兰腐败盛行，并要求任何新的欧盟援助都包括资金不被挪用的保证。他还表示，布拉迪斯拉发将停止向乌克兰提供军事支持。

“乌克兰是世界上最腐败的国家之一，我们正在以保证欧洲资金（包括斯洛伐克）不被挪用为条件来调整过度的财政支持，”他说。

2018年，一名调查国家腐败的记者被谋杀后，菲科本人在街头抗议中辞去斯洛伐克总理职务。这位斯洛伐克政坛左翼资深人士多次否认贪污指控。

保加利亚总理尼古拉·登科夫对记者说：“我能说的是，他们两人都没有拒绝向乌克兰提供援助的可能性，即使是在很长一段时间内。”

“问题是，什么类型的援助以及如何使用它，我们如何确定，欧盟确定，这种援助得到了有效的利用，”他说。（1美元=0.9477欧元）

美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯和中国最高外交官王毅周五再次举行第二天的会议，两个敌对大国讨论如何管理分歧，同时为总统乔·拜登和习近平之间的峰会奠定基础。

王毅于周四晚抵达国务院，与布林肯举行会晤并共进晚餐。周五早上，两位外交官再次接触，在记者被带出闭门会议之前，他们与高级助手面对面坐在一张宽大的桌子旁。

王毅将于周五晚些时候前往白宫并会见美国国家安全顾问杰克·沙利文。 预计他还将与拜登交谈，尽管目前尚不清楚他们的互动会有多大。

王毅为期三天的访问是中美之间一系列外交接触中的最新一次，此行主要是为预计将于 11 月在旧金山举行的亚太经合组织领导人会议期间举行的习拜登峰会做准备。弗朗西斯科.中国尚未宣布习近平是否出席。

以色列与哈马斯的冲突给超级大国之间紧张的关系增添了新的动力，华盛顿希望北京能够利用其对伊朗的影响力，防止中东地区的战争升级为更广泛的战争。

周四，王告诉布林肯，两国存在分歧，需要“深入”和“全面”对话，以减少误解并稳定关系。 “我们不仅应该恢复对话，而且对话应该深入、全面，”王通过翻译说道。

拜登政府与北京的首要任务是防止两个最大经济体之间的激烈竞争以及在贸易、台湾、人权和南海等一系列问题上的分歧演变成冲突。

然而，尽管北京和华盛顿都表示要寻找可以合作的领域，而且习近平周三表示中国愿意就全球挑战进行合作，但专家预计不会立即取得进展。

一名美国高级官员周五表示，卡塔尔告诉美国，一旦危机得到解决，卡塔尔将重新考虑哈马斯在卡塔尔的存在，以确保巴勒斯坦激进组织劫持到加沙的数十名人质获释。

该官员称，美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯和卡塔尔埃米尔谢赫·塔米姆·本·哈马德·阿勒萨尼本月在多哈举行的一次会议上达成了这一谅解，《华盛顿邮报》首先报道了这一情况。

这个海湾国家正在与美国协调，牵头与哈马斯和以色列官员就释放巴勒斯坦组织 10 月 7 日跨境袭击中被俘的 200 名人质进行调解谈判。

这个富裕的天然气生产国通过与以色列和哈马斯的对话释放了四名人质。

周三，卡塔尔总理表示，海湾阿拉伯国家为确保释放哈马斯扣押的人质而进行的谈判正在取得进展，他希望很快就能取得突破。

哈马斯于 2012 年在多哈设立了政治办公室，包括该组织领导人伊斯梅尔·哈尼亚和前领导人哈立德·梅沙尔在内的几位哈马斯官员定期在多哈度过。

谢赫·穆罕默德同时表示，政治办公室的目的是“作为沟通和为该地区带来和平与平静的一种方式，而不是煽动任何战争。”他表示，保持沟通渠道畅通非常重要。

据国家通讯社塔斯社报道，俄罗斯物理学家阿纳托利·古巴诺夫周五因叛国罪被莫斯科一家法院判处 12 年最高安全流放地监禁。

他是近年来因涉嫌向外国人传递敏感材料而被指控犯有叛国罪的众多俄罗斯科学家中最新的一位。克里姆林宫的批评者表示，逮捕有时是出于毫无根据的偏执，但当局否认了这一点。

古巴诺夫曾在莫斯科一家研究所工作，于 2020 年 12 月被捕，并被指控泄露有关俄罗斯航空业的机密信息。

他同一部门的同事瓦列里·戈卢布金 (Valery Golubkin ) 因向“外国组织代表”泄露国家机密罪而于 6 月因叛国罪被判处 12 年监禁。

俄罗斯议会今年4月投票决定将叛国罪的最高刑罚从20年提高到无期徒刑。西伯利亚一家研究所的三名高超音速导弹科学家目前也面临叛国罪指控。

缅因州警方将全天候搜寻美国陆军预备役军人罗伯特·R·卡德 (Robert R. Card) 的行动延长至周五，他是周三刘易斯顿一家酒吧和保龄球馆发生大规模枪击事件的主要嫌疑人，该枪击案造成 18 人死亡、13 人受伤。

官员敦促数万名该地区居民为了安全而留在室内。

周四晚上，电视直播了部分搜查行动，官员们在卡德居住的缅因州鲍登附近的小镇执行了几项搜查令。

执法人员包围了卡德在树林里的房子两个多小时，一名联邦调查局特工通过扩音器发出命令“举起双手出来”，但显然里面没人。

缅因州公共安全部发言人表示，行动开始时，警方并不知道卡德是否在里面，放大的信息是“标准搜查令公告”。

刘易斯顿是安德罗斯科金河岸上一个拥有 38,000 人的前纺织中心，自周三晚上的袭击以来，该地区和邻近社区已基本关闭，以便数百名警察能够进行搜查。该地区的大学和公立学校连续第二天停课。

路上几乎没有汽车，外面只有几个人，刘易斯顿市中心的许多企业都关门了。携带步枪和防弹背心的安全人员守卫着医院，许多枪击受害者都被送往医院。

40 岁的卡德是附近美国陆军预备役基地的一名中士，执法官员称他今年夏天被暂时送往精神卫生机构。

枪击事件发生当晚，缅因州警方在缅因州里斯本的一个船只下水处发现了一辆他们认为卡德逃跑时使用的白色SUV，距离刘易斯顿东南约7英里（11公里）。公开记录显示，他至少拥有一艘由 Sea-Doo 制造的船只，该公司以摩托艇闻名。

这场流血事件让安德罗斯科金县的城镇感到不安，这些城镇正受到就地避难的命令，因为它们加入了越来越多的美国遭受枪支屠杀的社区行列。

“这是一个小镇。你会认识每个人，”里斯本的肯斯伯丁说。 “但几年前我曾告诉我的妻子，‘亲爱的，问题不在于是否，而在于何时。’”

根据枪支暴力档案馆的数据， 美国四人或四人以上枪击事件预计将从 2022 年的 647 起增至 2023 年的 679 起。

据缅因州警方称，周三袭击中丧生的人数接近缅因州每年发生的凶杀案数量，自 2012 年以来缅因州每年发生的凶杀案一直在 16 至 29 起之间波动。

比尔·杨的兄弟罗布·杨告诉路透社， 受害者包括比​​尔·杨和他 14 岁的儿子亚伦，他们在 Just-In-Time Recreation 保龄球馆被枪杀。

布莱恩·麦克法兰 (Bryan MacFarlane) 的姐姐凯里·布鲁克斯 (Keri Brooks) 告诉美国有线电视新闻网 (CNN)，死者中还有 40 岁的布莱恩·麦克法兰 (Bryan MacFarlane)，他是一名聋人社区团体的成员，在参加 Schengees Bar & Grille 的沙坑锦标赛时被杀。

根据兰德公司 2020 年的一项研究，缅因州对枪支的管制较轻，大约一半的成年人生活在拥有枪支的家庭中。

缅因州购买或携带枪支不需要许可证，也没有像其他一些州那样允许执法部门暂时解除被认为危险的人的武装的所谓“红旗”法律。

来自刘易斯顿的民主党众议员贾里德·戈尔登告诉记者，这些袭击事件改变了他对禁止某些类型半自动步枪的反对意见。

戈登在新闻发布会上说：“我现在呼吁美国国会禁止使用突击步枪，就像我家乡这起大规模屠杀的凶手所使用的那样。”

但国会基本上无法通过枪支管制，即使在2012年康涅狄格州纽敦桑迪胡克小学发生屠杀、20名一年级学生和6名成年人被枪杀等悲剧发生之后也是如此。

2022 年 美国最高法院具有里程碑意义的裁决使枪支法的通过变得更加困难。法院认为，宪法赋予个人在公共场合携带武器的权利，并且立法者只能通过类似于 18 世纪美国的枪支法规。

经过数周的无情轰炸后，以色列准备在加沙发动地面攻势，巴勒斯坦飞地的一些居民表示，他们已准备好徒手对抗中东最强大的军队。

“即使我们所有的人都死了，我们也会战斗，”乌姆·莫阿塔塞姆·阿拉米说，他的房子在以色列空袭中被击中。

“尽管我们受了伤，但我们不会被他们所做的一切吓倒。即使用指甲，我们也会把他们赶出我们的土地，”她说。

以色列表示正在准备发动地面入侵，但美国和阿拉伯国家敦促以色列推迟行动，因为这将导致人口稠密的沿海地带平民伤亡人数成倍增加，并可能引发更广泛的冲突。

人们还担心，地面入侵会对加沙执政的伊斯兰哈马斯运动和其他武装组织据报道扣押的 200 多名人质意味着什么。

穆罕默德·阿布·达卡和他的家人不会冒险，特别是在以色列发动了一系列小规模入侵之后。由于以色列轰炸的强度，他离开了位于加沙地带南部汗尤尼斯以东的阿巴桑卡比拉镇的家。

他们住在联合国避难所内的帐篷里。和其他巴勒斯坦人一样，他不希望重蹈 Nakba 的覆辙，Nakba 是阿拉伯语中的灾难一词，指的是 1948 年以色列发动的战争，这场战争导致了他们的大规模被剥夺。

在围绕以色列建国的战争中，大约 70 万巴勒斯坦人（英国统治下的巴勒斯坦阿拉伯人口的一半）逃离或被赶出家园，并且被拒绝返回。许多人最终去了约旦、黎巴嫩和叙利亚以及加沙、约旦河西岸和东耶路撒冷。

“这是我们的土地，他们在里面与我们作战，我们还要在这种流血和苦难中持续多久？”说

阿布·达卡。 “任何敢来这里的人，无论是谁，我们都会杀了他。”

哈马斯控制的加沙卫生部周四表示，7,326名巴勒斯坦人在报复性空袭中丧生，其中包括3,038名儿童。

以色列和美国表示，他们对加沙卫生部的数据表示怀疑，但他们没有提供自己的估计。

以色列称，哈马斯在 10 月 7 日的暴乱中杀害了约 1,400 人，其中包括儿童。

据哈马斯附属媒体报道，巴勒斯坦武装分子在加沙地带至少两个地区与以色列军队发生冲突，这是几次小规模入侵中的最新一次。以色列军方没有立即证实此次出动。

加沙中部的居民表示，他们听到了听起来像是交火的声音，以及边境沿线的猛烈炮击和空袭，以色列飞机投掷照明弹和炸弹。

加沙平民变得更加绝望

随着加沙 230 万平民在电力、水以及食品、燃料和药品供应被切断的围困下变得更加绝望，援助问题于周五在纽约召开的由 193 个成员国组成的联合国大会上得到了讨论。

与联合国安理会本周未能通过关于援助加沙的决议不同，阿拉伯国家呼吁停火的决议没有否决权，该决议不具有约束力，但具有政治影响力。

三周内生产了大约 84 辆卡车。联合国表示，加沙每天需要大约 100 辆救援卡车，该官员表示，正在与以色列进行谈判，以寻找更快的机制，以阻止资源到达哈马斯。

Eight Indian former naval officers who were handed the death penalty by a court in Qatar on Thursday were charged with spying for Israel, a source in India and another in Qatar said.

Neither New Delhi nor Doha has officially stated the charges against the eight who were arrested in August 2022.

In India, a government official aware of Doha's stance said the Qatar authorities had accused them of spying for Israel.

The eight Indians will be able to appeal the death sentence, the source briefed on the case in Qatar told Reuters, as well as also saying they had been charged with spying for Israel.

Both sources spoke on condition of anonymity given the sensitivity of the case.

A spokesperson for India's foreign ministry did not respond to a request for comment about the sources' comments.

There was no immediate reply from Qatar's foreign ministry.

There was no immediate response from the prime minister's office in Jerusalem, which oversees Israel's intelligence services.

The ruling comes as Doha is trying to negotiate with the Palestinian militant group Hamas for the release of over 200 hostages seized during its Oct. 7 rampage in Israel, which is pummelling Gaza with aerial strikes in response.

The case involving the eight Indians, who were working on a submarine project with a private company for the Qatari authorities, could also become a diplomatic headache for New Delhi, which depends heavily on Qatar for its natural gas needs.

The Indian government said on Thursday that it was "deeply shocked" that Qatar's Court of First Instance had awarded the death penalty to the eight Indians, adding it was "exploring all legal options".

New Delhi had said that it attaches "high importance to this case" and will "take up the verdict with Qatari authorities".

The government said it would not comment further due to the "confidential nature of the proceedings".

Jairam Ramesh, a spokesperson for India's opposition Congress party urged the Indian government on Thursday to "use its diplomatic and political leverage with the Qatar government" to do utmost to get them released at the earliest.

President Volodymyr Zelenskiy's top diplomatic adviser said officials from up to 70 nations will meet in Malta to discuss Ukraine's vision for peace this weekend, rejecting the idea that cracks are appearing in allied support for Kyiv.

The talks on Saturday and Sunday will bring together national security advisers and foreign ministry officials to discuss Zelenskiy's 10-point blueprint for a peace settlement, as Russia's war grinds through its 21st month with no end in sight.

The talks, which do not involve Russia, will help gauge Ukraine and the West's ability to drum up continued and broader support, particularly in the Global South, as the conflict in Israel dominates headlines, moving the focus from Kyiv.

Ihor Zhovkva, Zelenskiy's adviser, said some nations were still confirming their plans, but that up to 70 were expected in Malta, up from the 43 who attended the previous round in Jeddah in August, and the 15 who went to Copenhagen for talks in June.

"You can clearly see this is a growing number of countries compared to Jeddah and it's very important it will be representatives of countries of all the continents," he told Reuters in an interview in his office in Kyiv late on Thursday.

The Zelenskiy formula's 10 points include calls for the restoration of Ukraine's territorial integrity, withdrawal of Russian troops, protection of food and energy supplies, nuclear safety and the release of all prisoners.

Zhovkva declined to name the countries that will attend, saying that could help Moscow lobby them not to come, but, asked whether Beijing would send an emissary, he said: "We are working with many countries, including China."

China, which has maintained close economic and diplomatic ties with Russia during the war, attended the talks in Jeddah.

Zhovkva said Kyiv still aimed to convene a Global Peace Summit this year.

"I cannot predict the discussion, but one of the most possible and desirable outcomes (of the Malta talks) will be to define the place and date of a peace formula summit at the level of heads of state and government."

MIDDLE EAST FALLOUT

Privately, Western officials say they are concerned the conflict in the Middle East will deal a setback to Ukraine's push to win over the Global South and that it will also distract attention from Ukraine's cause.

This week, European Union foreign policy chief Josep Borrell said he was worried that accusations of double standards in the West's view of the wars in Ukraine and the Middle East could result in fewer votes of support for Ukraine at the United Nations.

Zhovkva said he saw no evidence of diplomatic setbacks in the Global South, pointing to recent phone calls between Zelenskiy and the president of Turkey, the Saudi crown prince, the emir of Qatar and the president of South Africa. He said more contacts were planned.

He also said he did not believe the election of Mike Johnson as the new speaker of the US House of Representatives will deal a blow to vital military aid from the United States.

Johnson said on Thursday that he had concerns about Ukraine funding in general and he wanted to understand the "end game" in Ukraine.

Zhovkva said the election of a House speaker was a positive as it ended a three-week political vacuum and that he and Zelenskiy had not seen any signs of opposition to funding for Ukraine from either US party when they visited Washington in September.

"I analysed the words of newly elected speaker Mr Johnson before he was elected or even after he was elected and I haven't heard that he himself or members of his party are deciding to cut military support to Ukraine," he said.

Separately, in Brussels, most EU leaders said on Friday they backed a plan to support Ukraine with 50 billion euros ($53 billion) over the next four years, though Hungary and Slovakia voiced reservations ahead of a decision the bloc needs to take unanimously in December.

Colombians will choose mayors, governors and regional lawmakers in an election on Sunday which analysts say will serve as a referendum on the government of leftist President Gustavo Petro and could influence the 2026 presidential vote.

Sunday's vote is likely to emphasize the power of local and regional political families, as well as coalitions, rather than individual parties, according to analysts.

"There's a combination of factors. The opposition and traditional political sectors have tried to sell the elections as a referendum on the president and I believe that a lot of votes will be like that," said Green Alliance Senator Ariel Avila.

"There's going to be a big rap on the knuckles for (Petro's movement) Pacto Historico," he said.

Most candidates in Sunday's elections are backed by coalitions involving several parties or by signatures from citizens which allow them to run as independents.

"There's a very big dispute between traditional elites and new political forces. Most of the historic bosses have returned to the regions. Without a doubt, what's at stake here is the 2026 presidential campaign," Avila said.

Almost 39 million Colombians are eligible to vote on Sunday.

Campaigning has been marked by deteriorating security due to the presence of illegal armed groups - which remain active despite Petro's efforts to negotiate peace - and threats to candidates.

A recent report from the human rights ombudsman's office said more than 36% of municipalities face an extreme or high risk of violence during the elections, up from 23% in regional elections in 2019.

There is also a risk of electoral fraud, observers have warned.

"The main complaints have concerned irregularities on the part of serving public officials, and in advertising and the media," said Mauricio Vela, coordinator of advocacy group the Electoral Observation Mission.

"However, during election day the most reported crimes tend to be the buying and selling of votes," he said.

  • Biden questions Palestinian reporting of death tolls
  • Palestinians release names of over 7,000 victims
  • International agencies say data broadly accurate

US President Joe Biden has cast doubt on casualty figures provided by Palestinian officials in Gaza , but international humanitarian agencies consider them broadly accurate and historically reliable.

Although there is no dispute that Israeli attacks on Gaza have killed many people since Hamas ran amok in southern Israel on Oct. 7, Biden said on Wednesday he had "no confidence in the number that the Palestinians are using", without saying why.

The health ministry in Hamas-controlled Gaza responded by releasing a 212-page document containing the names and identity numbers of around 7,000 Palestinians it said had been killed in the Israeli bombardment of the enclave.

International groups, even some operating in Gaza, and global media including Reuters are not able to verify the figures but reporters have seen large numbers of bodies.

UN and other international agencies say there can be small discrepancies between the final casualty numbers and those reported by the Gaza health ministry straight after attacks, but that they broadly trust them.

"We continue to include their data in our reporting and it is clearly sourced," the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) said in a statement to Reuters.

"It is nearly impossible at the moment to provide any UN verification on a day-to-day basis."

Dr Mike Ryan, Executive Director of the Geneva-based World Health Organization's Health Emergencies Programme, said last week figures released by both sides "may not be perfectly accurate on a minute-to-minute basis, but they grossly reflect the level of death and injury on both sides of that conflict."

New York-based Human Rights Watch also says the casualty figures have generally been reliable, and that it has not found big discrepancies in its verification of past strikes on Gaza.

"It's worth noting that the numbers that are coming out since October 7th are generally consistent or within logic for the scale of killings one would expect, given the intensity of bombardment in such a densely populated area," Omar Shakir, Israel and Palestine Director at Human Rights Watch, said.

"Those numbers are in line with what one might expect, given what we're seeing on the ground through testimony, through satellite imagery and otherwise," he told Reuters.

FIGURES BROADLY ALIGN

Underlining the difficulties in calculating death tolls, a World Health Organization official said on Friday the agency had received estimates that some 1,000 unidentified bodies were still buried under the rubble in Gaza and not yet included in death tolls. The official did not specify the source.

While Hamas controls Gaza and exercises tight control over information coming out of the enclave, formal responsibility for the health ministry still rests with the Palestinian Authority (PA) in the West Bank.

The PA is dominated by Fatah, the main Palestinian rival to Hamas, and is responsible for paying salaries and providing equipment to Gaza hospitals.

It reports casualty totals based on numbers it receives from hospitals, ambulances and emergency services, in coordination with the Red Crescent, a spokesman in Ramallah said.

He said victims are initially identified by age, sex and injury type, and full identities are confirmed later. The figures are initially reported in Gaza, and updated in Ramallah after they have been checked, but discrepancies are generally minimal, he said.

Israel has not provided its own estimated death toll.

There has been no big change in the way Palestinian authorities report casualties since the last big conflict between Israel and Hamas in 2014, when figures provided by various entities were not vastly different.

In a report published on its website on Nov. 3, 2015, the Palestinian health ministry said the number of people killed in the July-August 2014 conflict in Gaza was 2,322.

A UN-mandated commission of inquiry reported that 2,251 Palestinians had been killed.

Although Israel blamed Hamas for the majority of the deaths in Gaza, the Israeli Foreign Ministry said in a report following the conflict that 2,125 Palestinians had been killed in Gaza, according to data gathered by the Israeli military.

The Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs, an Israeli think tank, said more than 2,100 Palestinians were killed, while rights groups B'tselem put that figure at 2,202 Palestinians.

ISRAELI CONCERN

Israel has been attacking Gaza since cross-border raids in which it said 1,400 people were killed by Hamas in southern Israel. Biden, who was speaking at a press conference, did not explain on Wednesday why he lacked confidence in the casualty figures provided by the Palestinians.

An Israeli military spokesman said this week the Gaza health ministry "continuously inflates the number of civilian casualties" and "has been caught lying in the past".

He cited the ministry's handling of an attack at Al-Ahli al-Arabi Hospital in Gaza on Oct. 17 which each side blamed on the other, saying the ministry initially reported 500 dead but later revised the toll down to 471. In a separate media briefing, another spokesman gave no Israeli casualty estimate when asked by reporters what Israel assessed the overall total to be.

An unclassified US intelligence report seen by Reuters estimated the death toll in the hospital attack was "probably at the low end of the 100 to 300 spectrum". An Israeli official has said the toll appears to be "several dozen".

Palestinian officials said calculating the number of dead in the attack had been difficult because some victims were dismembered, meaning there were many body parts to identify.

一年前，当中国共产党公布其205名中央委员会成员名单时，有一个明显的遗漏：总理李克强。

李克强于周五因心脏病去世，享年 68 岁，他被排除在外似乎证实了许多人长期以来的假设——他的经济改革方案已被正式放弃，取而代之的是国家主席习近平的国家主导的经济方针。 。

在努力重振疲软的消费需求并抵御日本式的经济停滞之际，改革再次成为中国政策制定者和分析人士关注的焦点。

但习近平领导下的中国并没有推动许多经济学家所倡导的变革，例如重新城镇化和为私营企业提供更多空间，而是将更多权力交到了国家手中。

“毫不夸张地说，一个可以稳步推进改革的时代已经结束，”一位不愿透露姓名的政府政策顾问表示。

李克强在担任中国第二高领导人和私营企业倡导者十年后于三月退休，但在习近平使自己成为中国几十年来最强大的领导人并加强对经济和社会的控制后，他的权力受到限制。

这位拥有精英北京大学经济学博士学位的英语国家总理致力于改善企业家的条件、吸引外国投资者、减少繁文缛节和提高穷人的收入。

但北京在 2013 年推出的雄心勃勃的市场化改革很快就遇到了麻烦，其中包括 2015 年因货币改革失败而引发的股市崩盘。在习近平的领导下，世界第二大经济体逐渐回归旧政策，这些政策加剧了中国的债务负担和工业产能过剩。

芝加哥大学政治学教授杨大利表示，“在习近平主席的领导下，李克强的决策和执行范围变得更加从属，习近平毫不掩饰地主导着政治和政策制定，使李克强沦为次要角色。”

ALLIES

中国的经济奇迹始于1978年，当时邓小平发起了历史性改革，允许更多的私营企业发展并向外国投资开放经济。

李并不是唯一一位最终被排除在外的支持改革的领导人。前经济沙皇刘鹤、前银监会郭树清、前央行行长易纲均已离开政府。

相反，习近平在政府中塞满了他的盟友，其中大多数是国际或金融经验有限的官员。

北京正在推出新一轮刺激措施以提振经济复苏，但经济学家警告称，中国可能会陷入长期通货紧缩和增长停滞，从而无法提高14亿人民的生活水平。

一些政府顾问一直在大力推动改革，重点是刺激城市化和家庭消费能力，减少对投资的依赖，并在国有企业和私营企业之间创造公平的竞争环境。

预计将于 11 月召开的共产党全会历来侧重于改革，但可能会让那些等待重大变革的人失望。

“我预计改革不会取得任何突破，”政府政策顾问表示。

A Pakistani court declined bail on Friday to detained former Prime Minister Imran Khan in a case in which he has been indicted on charges of leaking state secrets, his lawyer said.

The charge is related to a classified cable sent to Islamabad by Pakistan's ambassador in the United States last year, which Khan is accused of making public.

Former cricket star Khan denies that and said the contents of the cable appeared in the media from other sources.

Lawyer Naeem Panjutha said the Islamabad High Court declined Khan's application for bail and for the case to be dismissed.

"We will challenge it," he said in a post on the social media platform X, formerly known as Twitter.

Khan has been at the centre of months of political turmoil in nuclear-armed Pakistan that has shone a spotlight on the powerful military's influence over civilian politics.

Khan was forced from office in 2022 after losing a no-confidence vote in parliament. He said at the time the military was trying to sideline him after he fell out with the generals over disagreements about top security appointments.

The military, which has ruled Pakistan directly for significant periods since independence in 1947, and wielded influence over civilian governments at other times, denied engineering Khan's ouster.

Khan has said the cable he has been accused of leaking was proof of a US conspiracy to push the military to oust him in the 2022 parliamentary vote because he had visited Moscow just before Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

Both the United States and the Pakistani military denied that.

Khan has had dozens of legal cases filed against him, which he has denounced as an effort to keep him out of politics.

He has been convicted in one graft case and sentenced to three years in jail. The sentence was suspended but he remains in prison in connection with other cases.

Given his conviction, Khan, whose conservative, nationalistic agenda won him considerable public support, can not take part in a general election expected early next year.

但巴勒斯坦死亡人数迅速上升，解救哈马斯扣押的人质遇到困难，阿拉伯国家、欧洲盟友和一些美国人的强烈抗议，促使拜登团队支持人道主义暂停以色列的袭击，并专注于获得援助政府内外的多位消息人士称，对巴勒斯坦人来说。

一名白宫官员表示，这种语气的转变是基于加沙人道主义危机恶化的“实地事实”以及拜登团队“与世界各国的对话”。

一位与现任官员保持联系的前官员表示，拜登及其顾问之间围绕美国的信息展开了一场幕后拉锯战。

这位前官员表示：“我们看到了从对以色列的全力、无条件拥抱到更加细微差别的演变。”

一位不愿透露姓名的美国官员表示，美国政府没有预料到巴勒斯坦伤亡人数会如此之快——当地官员称，加沙目前已有 7,000 多人死亡——也没有预料到人道主义局势会如此迅速恶化。

卡内基研究中心中东问题专家亚伦·戴维·米勒表示：“我认为，为了应对不断变化的情况，以及如果以色列大规模进攻加沙，似乎迫在眉睫的更大灾难，框架显然已经发生了变化，这并不令人意外。”国际和平基金会。

80 岁的拜登在面对充满挑战的 2024 年连任竞选、一些潜在支持者因他不支持巴勒斯坦人而威胁不投票，以及前总统巴拉克·奥巴马警告以色列的行动可能适得其反时，已经发生了变化。

以色列官员及其美国支持者私下向路透社表示担忧，自10月7日哈马斯犯下暴行以来，随着时间的推移，世界的焦点将越来越集中在以色列袭击加沙造成的死亡和破坏上。

一位美国消息人士称，拜登的助手敦促以色列同行在全面地面入侵之前花更多时间仔细考虑退出策略。

消息人士补充说，美国官员警告说，像美国在伊拉克战争早期阶段经常发生的那样，“即时”制定此类战略的细节将是一个错误。

另一位熟悉情况的消息人士称，派往该地区的美国军事顾问敦促以色列同行保持谨慎，因为任何入侵部队都将面临艰难的战斗地形以及密集的隧道和布满诱杀装置的建筑物，这可能会增加以色列士兵和加沙平民的伤亡。谈话说。

拜登的民主党前任、前任老板奥巴马罕见地就一场活跃的外交政策危机发表评论，他本周警告称，以色列切断对加沙的粮食和水供应可能会“导致几代人的巴勒斯坦态度变得更加强硬”。

当被问及政府是否与拜登的民主党前任协调时，白宫没有回应。

阿拉伯领导人的压力

当哈马斯武装分子于10月7日冲出加沙并袭击以色列南部时，拜登全力支持以色列，称他向以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡转达“以色列有权保卫自己和人民。完全停止。” ”

他没有提到巴勒斯坦人民。

10月11日，美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯在启程前往中东之前向记者发表讲话时表示，他此行的首要目标是大力表明与以色列的团结，包括提供以色列自卫所需的所有军事装备。

“美国支持以色列，”布林肯说。他根本没有提到人道主义援助。

在布林肯为期六天的访问期间，加沙因以色列空袭造成的死亡人数激增，人们对食物和水的担忧也日益增加。布林肯在该地区会见的每一位阿拉伯领导人都敦促他紧急找到解决加沙局势迅速恶化的办法。

布林肯转达了阿拉伯领导人的担忧，而其他人则直接与美国总统交谈。

上周巴勒斯坦一家医院发生爆炸后，针对以色列的强烈抗议活动也令美国官员感到震惊。美国和以色列都指责巴勒斯坦武装分子所为。

美国官员表示，这些抗议活动提醒人们，任何地面袭击都有升级的风险，因为它们表明以色列的对手可能如何利用虚假信息引发骚乱。

人道主义暂停

本周，美国政策发生了最迅速的转变，支持以色列停止对加沙的袭击，以允许援助进入和人们逃离​​。

10月23日，当被问及国际社会对人道主义暂停的要求时，白宫安全发言人约翰·柯比表示，美国希望确保“以色列拥有自卫和追击哈马斯所需的工具，并确保人道主义援助持续供应”。

一天后，柯比和布林肯公开倡导这样做。这一转变是在联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯呼吁保护平民以及联合国组织越来越迫切地呼吁允许援助之后发生的。

美国修改了自己的联合国决议，不再关注以色列的自卫权，而是呼吁采取一切措施，特别是人道主义暂停，以允许人道主义援助不受阻碍地进入。

拜登周三的言论与10月7日的言论形成鲜明对比，展现出新的方向。拜登在新闻发布会上说：“以色列必须尽其所能，尽管困难重重，以保护无辜平民。”

他还对约旦河西岸的以色列“极端主义定居者”提出了罕见的批评，指责他们火上浇油，并呼吁危机结束后“集中努力”，争取达成一项协议，让以色列一个新的巴勒斯坦国将和平共处。

但拜登也对巴勒斯坦对死亡人数的估计表示怀疑，并表示将继续坚定支持以色列。他在新闻发布会上表示，他对巴勒斯坦人使用的有关加沙死亡人数的数字“没有信心” 。
